awd_titl_txt: AF: Small: Collaborative Research: Mathematical Theory and Fast Algorithms for Rayleigh Quotient-type Optimizations
awd_abstract_narration:
Many modern data analysis techniques and applications in machine
learning try to learn what input data has the largest effects on the
outputs. Rayleigh Quotients (RQ), or, more generally, RQ-type
objective functions, are the basis of a mathematical technique that
captures this information. This project conducts in-depth theoretical
and algorithmic studies of three RQ-type optimizations: robust RQ
optimizations that can handle data uncertainty, constrained RQ-type
optimizations that can incorporate prior information from image
segmentation or data clustering, and trace ratio optimizations that
can perform multi-view spectral clustering.  This project improves
understanding of this practically important and user-oriented
mathematical theory, creating computational methods that are embodied
in open-source software.  It not only advances mathematical theory
and optimization algorithms in data science, but trains computer
science and computational mathematics graduate students in
interdisciplinary knowledge and tools necessary to undertake the
project successfully. The PIs also involve undergraduate students
in all aspects of this research project.

The PIs expect to produce a unified view of RQ-type optimizations,
reformulating them into linear and nonlinear eigenvalue problems for
which new variational principles can characterize the optimal
solutions.  These new principles should expose the numerical linear
algebra characteristics of the underlying problems, supporting the
development of fast algorithms that exploit the mathematical
properties and sparse data structure.

por.por_cntn:
Data Science comprises diverse disciplines of data-related
researches and practices. New ideas emerge daily to tackle various
tasks such as multi-view clustering and image
segmentation/extraction. Often real world data are contaminated
with noises, some of which may be even intentional. While it is not
possible to put today's researches in Data Science, as a vast
emerging field, under one mathematical framework, we have found a
recurring mathematical formulation in a wide range of data science
applications, name the RQ-type (Rayleigh Quotient) optimizations.

Four major outcomes of the project are as follows. The first one is
a detailed convergence analysis for the so-called Self-Consistent
Field (SCF) iteration for eigenvector-dependent nonlinear
eigenvalue problems (NEPv) which frequently bridge certain RQ-type
optimizations and their efficient solutions by modern numerical
linear algebra techniques. This work is expected to also
significantly impact computational chemistry and physics in the
areas of electronic structural calculations where SCF is dominantly
used for solving the Kohn-Sham equation. The second one is about
the linear constrained eigenvalue problem from image
segmentation/extraction. We have established a complete and
rigorous mathematical theory of the eigenvalue problem and, as a
result, highly efficient Lanczos methods that are particularly
useful for imaging processing because these problems are usually of
high dimension. The third outcome is the first quantitative
convergence analysis for generalized Lanczos trust-region method
for the large scale trust-region subproblems. We integrated our
results with the popular open source software GLTR and considerably
improved the overall performance of the package. Finally, the
project has led us to expand our research to another kind of
RQ-type optimization from canonical correlation analysis (CCA), a
cornerstone of linear dimensionality reduction techniques. CCA has
been evolving quickly these days into two-view orthogonal CCA and
multi-view orthogonal CCA. Some progress has been made and more is
expected in years ahead.

We combined our research activities closely with student training.
Five PhD students successfully defended their theses and graduated
with doctor degrees during the project period.
